But there was a story that when Nurse Griffiths, when David was born, it was the winter of 1939

home from the nursing home and he was very sickly and they didn't quite know what to do.
So Nurse Griffiths, now there were no cars, there was nothing, Nurse Griffiths came over
and they would have walked across fields in those days and she said to my mother and father
in law, you give me the baby, you bring him down, I'll look after him, otherwise he'll
die.
So that's what happened and she kept him for several weeks and kept him alive.
I don't quite know what was wrong and every night David's father, after he had milked,
put a sack around himself and he'd walk down to the common, which would be a little way
across the fields or round the road, whichever, and he said that he could hear the icicles
banging on the trees.
Anyway a couple of weeks later they brought the baby back.

So why would you have gone there?
In those days we had a system of you had to pass your 11 plus exam to go to a grammar
school.
If you didn't you went to a secondary modern school.
And I guess my parents felt it might benefit me not going to a secondary school.
So it was a fee-paying school.
It was private.
They had a system that they would take Catholic children if they passed the 11 plus without
fees.
So a lot of families had the chance to go there who couldn't probably afford it otherwise.
I passed the entrance exam to go.
My father paid the fees.
I went along with, as I say, quite a few other farmers' daughters.
If you weren't clever that's what you did.
So what was it like?
Oh absolutely, absolutely brilliant.

Well, we're pretty sure this house, the barn especially, was built by the monks because
they had a grange and a moor barn, which is over on the common.

living here.

So do you as a farmer down here Sue, what are the challenges or the delights?
So, you know, I think that the drainage, the grips, that sort of thing that maybe a farmer
elsewhere wouldn't have to deal with.
Well, over my life for farming, 55 years now, when I came here, yes, there were grips in
all the fields.
And then you had to consider the cost of draining your land to get rid of these grips.
So, we put under drainage in, we ploughed and we reseeded nearly the entire farm.
Why did you get rid of the grips?
Well, when you're farming and you've got, the machinery was improving and if you were
mowing a field, the difficulty of mowing these grips was incredible.
I'd have to go and rake back as David was mowing and they would break the machinery
because you'd go down and there were verus, you see, all the fields had verus.
So, you just needed to have flat fields for all your crops.
It made it easier for harvesting, made it easier for everything.
We filled in blind ditches.
There were often blind ditches where nothing had been done for centuries, you see.
And that mean you were then by flattening the fields?
Yes.
What did you have to do a lot then with making alternative drainage?
No, because you put an under drainage system in.
That must have been massive.

Gosh.

In the 60s they were handing grants out because they were so short of food.

And we were building our dairy herd up, which was very necessary to be as efficient
as you possibly could.
And so, are there farms down here that still use that sort of system, the grip system?

I used to help run the church.

My mother became very ill and I had to look after her.
There was an awful lot going on.
And it wasn't probably until 2000.
I used to help my girls run their businesses because one was a ceramicist and the other made clothes and whatever.
So there was all that going on and the cows, which took most of our life up.
And I started writing my book of my life story, thinking, well, this would be nice for the grandchildren
to know a little bit about when I used to say we had no hot water in the house.
We didn't have a bathroom. We didn't have electric.
And this was our life.
And my word, we were happy.
It never made any difference to us.
My mother created a wonderful home with very little.
My father and mother worked hard with the business to afford to pay for the four of us to go to private school,
which must, looking back, have been a great sacrifice for them.
But they thought maybe it would do us good.
There was all sorts of things that made me realize that we had a different life to other people.
And I guess I started writing it down because my own family, it was such a large family,
all very interesting people who did things that you didn't hear about other people doing.
So you've written that, have you Sue?
Not all of it. No, no, nothing like.
I've got quite a few chapters under my belt.

You just can't encompass it all.

All the people, who they were, what they did and how we lived.
Who was Hubert Jones?
Hubert Jones. Well, you see, his family, the Joneses, I don't know how far they go back,
but I know it's hundreds of years.
And again, they had their own land.
So if people had their own land, they stayed.
He was one of several boys.
I don't quite know how many.
His daughter, Lynn, lives in Redwick,
and she gave me access to all his papers that he'd written.
And he had been writing his history since I would think he was about 30 or 40.
So his memories went right back to the beginning of the 1900s.
And he sketched. He would go.
He didn't drive, but he would go by bus into the library and he would order books.
And they always sent them by post so that he would read his book
and then correspond with the head librarian, send them back.
So everything he wrote or copied, rather, to do with the history was factual.
He didn't do a bibliography as such,
but he wrote down which book it had come out of so that I know that it's not fiction.
And then he was writing, and I can show you.
I have written stuff myself, which has copied down a lot of his memories.
This is what's fascinated me, what he can tell us.
You see, there's Broad Street Common in the parish of Goukli,
and the land was once part of the estate of the College of Eden.
Now, his diction wasn't terribly good.
He was not terribly good at putting words into sentences, if you know what I mean.
And he was very clever, but I've sort of rewritten what he had done
so that it makes perhaps a little more sense to people listening these days.
It would have made more sense to him at the time when he was writing it.
And here he's like, I remember.
So everything's I remember.
And this was the fascinating bit.
I'll just read the first bit.
I remember there had been talk of a large docks being built on the Nash side of the River Usk.
However, it did not materialize as the 1914-18 War changed everything,
putting an end to all the dreams of new prosperity.

Are you too young to remember the war?

Second World War.

So do you remember the winter of 63?
Oh, gosh, yes.
Yes.
What was it like here?
Oh, horrendous.
Horrendous.
Here, well, and I remember especially the 83 one, and I took pictures and film of the 83 one here.
But 63, people couldn't move around.
And it stayed from Boxing Day until March almost.
And here especially, all the water froze.
And they were trying to get specialist people to come and unfreeze the water under the pill and came in under the pill.
Because that would have been particularly here.
Yes. The only water supply in the house, we had a huge water tank in the attic.
And they would carry churns of water up there every day to fill it.
And I think David had probably 50 head of cattle in the sheds.
And they drink, I don't know how many, 25 gallons a day.
And they had to carry water from the pill, because it was a running stream, up to the sheds every day.
There was an Italian man working here at the time.
And most of their day was taken up between milkings and just hauling water.
And it was cruel, you know.
There was ice on every reen.
Gosh.
You couldn't turn the cattle out anyway, which you wouldn't have done.
So, oh no.
David, he could talk for ages on that.
It was horrendous.
And the drought of 76, was that equally as bad?
Oh, terrible for us. Terrible.
We always reared all our heifers, because heifers were very expensive to buy in 76.
So we had about 23.
Now, we would have had 70 or 80 cows at the time.
And there was no fodder in the winter.
In the summer there was no grass for them.
And we had to feed straw, because it was the only thing we had.
We had to keep what hay we had for the winter feed.
Was straw not a good thing to feed, Kathy?
No, it hurts their mouths.
Oh, really? Yeah.
So we went into silage in those days.
It hadn't taken off.
And we'd taken land all over the place.
We always had to buy 100 acres, very nearly, of grass keep, as we call it.

We had some at Wilcric.
We had some at Redwick.
And our cattle were starving.
We had to feed them straw.

And when it came to the time we had nothing left, we had to sell our heifers.
Oh, God. It was that desperate?
It was desperate.

Newport. Would you consider Newport to be part of the levels?

No. Up as far as Summerton.

And they go over.

And that would have been levels going back 150 years.

Once we get up through Liswery, we don't think of it any longer as being part of the Moors as we called it.
So was Newport the place where you would go shopping or livestock market?
Oh, yes, yes.
The fresh fruit and veg market?
Oh, definitely. On a Wednesday, the farmers would go to market.
Their wives didn't drive, so the wives went.
And I remember all my aunts who were farmers' wives who had all meeting Newport.
Every shop, every building was a shop with something that people needed.
And the market was a hive of industry.
Griffin Street, where our shop was, was alive with shops.
And people could park anywhere.
I remember we used to park outside the town hall where the clock was because the bank was next door.
I remember feeding the babies in the car.
We used to take hot water flasks to feed.
And you met everybody. You bumped into people.
There was every type of business you could imagine.
Expensive jewellery shops, beautiful cafes, all with different character of their own.
And you always had a second story like the Cardoma where you could look down into the street and see what's around.
Beautiful dress shops, lovely stores.
I can remember one shop EG Taylor where they had a machine that took your money and it flew right across the shop on a chain.
And it came out the other end and then you had to change back and unscrew these little pots and your money would be in it.
So, yeah, beautiful shoe shops, wonderful tailors, bespoke tailors as well.
I can remember my father having his coats made with this bespoke tailor and his shoes.
He used to wear britches up to his knees.
Britches, no, what do you call them?
Leggings.
Leggings up to the top of his britches.
That wood button.
Yes, that's it.
He used to wear those and sports coats he'd have made.
Yellow waistcoats.
And my mother used to have her suits tailored.
Oh yes, Newport was alive and gorgeous properties like the town hall and the library and everything.
And they just knocked it all down.
And the Lyceum Theatre with these wonderful structure with all these pillars, a bit like Covent Garden, the Opera House.
And I can remember my mother taking me to pantomimes there and seeing ice skating on ice in those days.
There were music halls, there were dance places.
It was just wonderful.
And we used to have a carnival and we'd be taken in and you'd sit on the windows of the bank or something and wait for the carnival to go past.
It was huge.
But the population of Newport wouldn't have been any more than about 25,000 in those days, maybe 30.
And now we're looking at 100 and not 1000.
It sounds like it was a thriving place.
Oh it was.
But you had lots of industry and the docks were huge then too, weren't they?
Yes, there was industry down there and of course there was Lysats and all the other places, all of that.
But the farmers would stand market Fridays and Saturdays and the market, at the top of the market you had this huge floor
where all the farmers would have their chicken and their produce, their butter and their cream all the way round.
And our shop was absolutely thriving in Griffin Street because people could pull up outside the market opposite the shop.
We had mobile shops that used to go around the villages on a Tuesday.
Oh really?
They would deliver all the meat on a Saturday for people's roasts in all the villages.
So all my aunts and uncles worked in this business.
So it was one of the bigger butchers' shops in Newport.
And yes, and I was told many stories by many people that during the war,
my grandfather used to supply an awful lot of businesses with meat.
But on a Saturday night, there were a lot of people down the pill area and the poorer areas of Newport who didn't have money
and the kids would be without shoes and so forth.
And my grandfather would hold an auction on a Saturday night because they had no cold stores you see.
So all the meat that was killed had to be got rid of.
So he'd auction off this meat and he used to make sure he'd auction it off to people for nothing.
So they had meat for Sundays.
Wow.
If anybody came up with, looked a bit poor, he would make sure they had.
And one day I was with the NFU doing a stand-up job in Newport Square
trying to present to people what farmers could produce.
So we wanted them to know that we were still around producing their food.
And a little old lady came along and we got talking.
And she said, oh, I've always bought my stuff in the market and I liked fresh food.
And she said, and there was an old gentleman, Mr. Collymore, when we were children, we couldn't afford meat.
And my mother used to come and take us children down there and we'd always have something for Sunday.
And I thought, oh, well, that story was true.
Oh, that's lovely, isn't it?
It was nice to hear.
Yeah, yeah, to have it confirmed by a third party as well.
Yes, because a lot of people used to talk about it and I never knew for sure until this lady.
I thought, what a coincidence that I should talk to her.
